awd_titl_txt: EAGER:Experimental Deployment of the ARTEMIS BGP Hijacking Detection Prototype in Research and Educational Networks
awd_abstract_narration:
The Internet suffers from a design flaw affecting the security of global routing, exposing it to a class of large-scale attacks that can cause significant portions of network traffic to be diverted across the globe.  The potential impact of these attacks - known as BGP hijacking - can range from massive eavesdropping to identity spoofing or selective content modification. In addition, executing such attacks does not require access or proximity to the affected links and networks, posing increasing risks to national security. Recently, researchers at CAIDA, UC San Diego, proposed a novel methodology (called ARTEMIS) to detect and mitigate BGP hijacking attacks that is radically different from the state of the art but that network operators find promising and more in line with their needs.  In this project, researchers carry out a first experimental assisted deployment of ARTEMIS in few selected operator networks supporting education, research and other no-profit activities in the US.  This project significantly contributes to transitioning from a prototype mainly based on theoretical foundations and controlled experiments into a real platform that can be practically used by operators to secure their networks.  The project also contributes to improving the security of networks participating in the project, with an immediate positive effect on the security of infrastructure critical to our society. 

This project is a collaboration among researchers and selected research and education network operators to carry out an experimental deployment of ARTEMIS detection and mitigation techniques in their networks.  The main goals of such experimentation are: i) to evaluate the ARTEMIS methods and their implementation in real operational scenarios; ii) to learn and address real deployment technical issues; iii) to train operators in the use of the tool and contribute to improve the security of their networks.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Internet is vulnerable to a class of large-scale attacks--known as BGP route hijacking--with tremendous potential impact, threatening the confidentiality, integrity, and availability of network communications.  While the origin of these vulnerabilities lies in the design of the Internet global routing protocol (BGP), due to a mix of operational, regulatory, and economical issues, proactive solutions that address the problem at the root are struggling to take off. The vast majority of the defensive approaches adopted by network operators nowadays are therefore reactive, i.e., based on detecting and mitigating these attacks as they happen. 

However, due to a mix of technological and practical issues, current reactive approaches are largely inadequate: Detection is mainly provided by third-party services, that notify networks about suspicious events involving their prefixes, based on routing information.  Third-party approaches suffer from issues with regard to evasion, accuracy, speed, and confidentiality.  To overcome these issues, the Center for Applied Internet Data Analysis (CAIDA), at University of California San Diego, USA (www.caida.org) together with the INSPIRE group, FORTH, Greece (www.inspire.edu.gr) developed a methodology and an open-source prototype tool called ARTEMIS (Automatic and Real-Time dEtection and MItigation System)?This research effort was partially funded by the NSF.  The ARTEMIS approach allows a network operator to not have to rely on third party services (with consequent loss of privacy, lack of detection accuracy, and practical deployment issues) for the detection of BGP hijacking attacks. Instead, it empowers an operator to autonomously instantiate defense mechanisms that are more reliable, accurate and fast, by leveraging local knowledge of routing configuration. 

In this project, CAIDA carried out a first experimental assisted deployment in few selected operator networks supporting education, research, and other nonprofit activities in the U.S., such as Internet2, Merit Network, and Great Plains Network. The main goals of this experimentation were: i) to evaluate the ARTEMIS methods and their implementation in real operational scenarios; ii) to learn and address real deployment technical issues; iii) to train operators in the use of the tool and contribute to improve the security of their networks.  We successfully deployed the ARTEMIS tool in the networks of three targeted operators. Based on the feedback they provided during our collaboration, we have identified, prioritized, and implemented fixes, documentation improvements, and additional features. We have also trained the operators in the use of the ARTEMIS tool and contributed to improve the security of--as well as to identify routing misconfigurations--in their networks.

Thanks in part to the improvements we made and the training we performed, all collaborating institutions expect to continue running the ARTEMIS tool and are promoting its use to other organizations.  In addition, thanks to the experience developed in this project and its results in terms of improvements to the ARTEMIS software tool, we saw an increasing uptake by industry and among network operators (in addition to those participating in the pilot deployment during this project), including a major Internet Service Provider in the U.S. and two major Internet exchange points.  We broadly disseminated our results both to the scientific and operational community and engaged in collaboration with the industry, which benefited tech transfer and the professional development of graduate students.  Our collaborators at FORTH also set up a chat server with channels dedicated to assisting ARTEMIS users and we published and maintained documentation on GitHub (https://github.com/FORTH-ICS-INSPIRE/artemis).

This project resulted in a greater understanding of technical and practical challenges in deploying a reactive solution to the persistent problem of BGP?s lack of authentication that is radically different from the state of the art but that operators find promising and more in line with their needs. Second, this project significantly contributed to our effort to transition from a prototype mainly based on theoretical foundations and controlled experiments into a real platform that can be practically used by operators to secure their networks: at time of writing, the ARTEMIS open-source tool reached release v1.4. Finally, we helped to secure the educational and research networks that participated in this pilot project, with an immediate positive effect on the security of infrastructure critical to our society.
